chapter.title: ⪪ Installation
chapter.para: ⪪ is an add-on product for &sls; 11 systems. You can either install the ⪪ add-on together with your &sls; base system during the initial installation process, or on top of an already-installed base system at any later time. ⪪ can be obtained free of charge from .

If you install ⪪ on top of SLES with the latest maintenance patches applied, you may get dependency errors in some cases if you do not also use the latest ⪪ patches. To avoid those dependency errors, re-run Novell Customer Center (&ncc;) Configuration in &yast; right after you have added the ⪪ installation repository to your system, but before you install any packages from ⪪. This way the ⪪ update repository will be properly available to your system.

It is recommended to to check for ⪪ updates available immediately after installing the product. SUSE continuously releases maintenance updates for ⪪, and newer packages are likely to be available compared to those installed from media, for example using the zypper patch command.

note.title: Installation Scope
note.para: SMT is a LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP) based application. During the installation, Apache and MySQL will automatically be installed if missing.

sect1.title: Installation During the Initial Installation Process
sect1.para: To install the ⪪ add-on together with your base system during the initial installation process, follow these steps:

step.para: Start the &sls; 11 installation as usual. For more information, see the &sls; documentation coming with the base product.

To include the ⪪ add-on product, check the I would like to install an additional Add On product option during the isntallation and, if you are installing ⪪ from a local ISO image, select Local ISO Image as the media type (repository). If you are installing from a different source, such as CD, NFS, or HTTP, choose the appropriate type. Then click Next.
If you are installing from a CD, insert the ⪪ add-on product CD. If you are installing from a different source, provide the necessary repository information.
Confirm the ⪪ license agreement and click Next.

The ⪪ add-on product is displayed in the overview. Continue with the installation as usual. Make sure that the ⪪: Subscription Management Tool for SLE installation pattern is selected automatically and do not remove it.
A two-step ⪪ Configuration Wizard is shown during the final steps of the installation workflow. Configure ⪪ as described in and continue with the &sls; installation as usual.

sect1.title: Installation on Top of an Already Installed System
sect1.para: To install ⪪ on top of an already-installed base system, follow these steps:

step.para: Start &yast; and select Software Add-On Product . Then click Add.

If you are installing ⪪ from a local ISO image, select Local ISO Image as the media type (repository). If you are installing from a different source, such as CD, NFS, or HTTP, choose the appropriate type. Then click Next.
If you are installing from a CD, insert the ⪪ add-on product CD. If you are installing from a different source, provide the necessary repository information.
Confirm the ⪪ license agreement and click Next.
Click Accept to install the ⪪: Subscription Management Tool for SLE pattern.
Depending on the scope of already installed packages, the software manager will add more packages to resolve all dependencies. Confirm these Automatic Changes to perform the installation.
The ⪪ Configuration Wizard is launched. See .

sect1.title: ⪪ Configuration Wizard
sect1.para: During the installation of ⪪ the two-step ⪪ Configuration Wizard is launched, regardless of the used installation method. Configure ⪪ using this wizard. You are able to change the configuration later using the &yast; ⪪ Server Configuration module— see .

step.para: The Enable Subscription Management Tool service (⪪) option is checked by default. Uncheck it only if you want to disable the installed ⪪.
If the firewall is enabled, check Open Port in Firewall to allow access to the ⪪ service from remote computers.

Enter your &ncc; organization credentials in User and Password. If you do not know your &ncc; credentials, refer to . Test the entered credentials by pressing the Test button. ⪪ will connect to the Customer Center server using the provided credentials and download some testing data.
Enter the e-mail address you have used for the &ncc; registration into NCC E-mail Used for Registration.
Your ⪪ Server URL should contain the URL of the ⪪ server being configured. It is populated automatically.
Press Next to continue to the second configuration step.
For security reasons, ⪪ requires a separate user to connect to the database. With the Database Password for smt User widget set the database password for that user. Confirm it in the following field.
Enter all e-mail addresses that ⪪ should send reports to using the Add button. You are also able to Edit or Delete any incorrect or obsolete addresses.
Then click Next.
If the current MySQL root password is empty—as in any freshly installed system—you will be asked to enter a New MySQL Root Password.

sect1.title: Update of ⪪ From Previous Versions
sect1.para: This section contains the information about upgrading from the previous versions of ⪪.

sect2.title: Update from Subscription Management Tool 11 SP2
sect2.para: There are two ways of upgrading ⪪ 11 SP2 to ⪪ 11 SP3:

listitem.para: Perform the on-line migration, using the wagon tool. For more information, refer to the general documentation for SUSE Linux Enterprise Server.
When upgrading SLES 11 to SP3 via booting the installation media, add the ⪪ add-on product. This will make sure that the ⪪ packages get updated together with SLES 11.

sect3.title: MySQL Database Migration
sect3.para: SLES11-SP3 introduces the upgrade of the MySQL database to version 5.5. This upgrade involves a change of the database format and the database needs to be converted accordingly.

sect2.title: Update from Subscription Management Tool 10
sect2.para: In general, the update from ⪪ 10 is not supported. This is a list of issues that might occur if the update is performed:

listitem.para: There is a new optional value requiredAuthType in /etc/smt.conf to specify if authentication should be required to access the update repositories. If the value is not present in /etc/smt.conf, behavior is unchanged from ⪪ 10. See the ⪪ 11 manual for further details.

⪪ 11 does not use the registration URL from /etc/suseRegister.conf anymore, but reads the value [NU] NURegUrl from /etc/smt.conf. If the value is not present in /etc/smt.conf, the value from /etc/suseRegister.conf is used as a fallback.
The installed version of /etc/apache2/conf.d/nu_server.conf and /etc/apache2/conf.d/smt_mod_perl.conf will be replaced with a newer version.

sect3.title: Changes Related to Dropping Privileges by ⪪ Scripts

listitem.para: By default, all ⪪ scripts run under a new, unprivileged user named smt. The user can be defined in smt.conf.

In ⪪ 10, all files and repositories were owned by root. In ⪪ 11, the smt user needs write access to these repositories. To fix up the permissions, use the changeSMTUserPermissions.sh script shipped as part of the ⪪ package.

The &yast; proxy module writes the proxy information to /root/.curlrc. In ⪪ 11 the scripts are running with privileges dropped, therefore the .curlrc file in the home directory of the used user (smt by default) must be edited. Otherwise use smt.conf to define the proxy settings.

sect1.title: Migration between &scc; and &ncc;
sect1.para: ⪪ can talk to only one registration service (&scc;, &ncc;, alternatively also &slms;). The switch between the registration servers can be done either via a &yast; module or command-line tools.

Before performing the switch between customer centers, make sure that the target customer center serves all products that are registered against ⪪. Both &yast; and the command-line tools perform a check to find out whether all products can be served with the new registration server. If it is not possible, the only option is to install two parallel ⪪ instances and to synchronize products from both &scc; and &ncc;.

sect1.title: Enabling SLP Announcements
sect1.para: ⪪ already includes the SLP service description file (/etc/slp.reg.d/smt.reg). In order to enable SLP announcements of the ⪪ service, open respective ports in your firewall and enable the SLP service.
